common.text:
Ancient texts

Due to the frequent confusion with the literal interpretation of the Mesopotamian flood, we wrote a serie of four texts to help readers to undertstand what ancient authors were describing:

• (Texts with Sciences (Part I)): we study the concepts of "world" and "sky" in Mesopotamian cultures and how the lack of understanding of the surrounding environment may have led to the idea of an extraordinarily long lifespan, incompatible with human nature.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Part II)): we explore the water cycle and the law of conservation of mass. With this, we discussed how the concept of "world" in Mesopotamia differs from our own.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Part III)): we examined the epics of *Gilgamesh* and *Atrahasis*, as well as the Sumerian deluge narratives. Within them, we identified a recurring narrative pattern: a few people and animals are saved in a boat, described in various shapes (cubic or circular), following a divine punishment. From this, we established the probable periods in which these deluges occurred and compared them with data from other regions, concluding that there were no global floods.
  • (Texts with Sciences (Conclusion)): we concluded our study with an analysis of two different papers that mapped floods across the world at various times, providing context for the conditions under which Mediterranean authors wrote their texts.

Figura 2: Sumerian King List. Â© Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford (Ashmolean Image Library).

Uruk

The city of Uruk is recognized for its significant contributions to human history, including the invention of a writing system, architectural achievements in stone, the origin of ziggurats, and the development of the cylinder seal. Uruk is also famously associated with Gilgamesh, the semi-legendary king and protagonist of an epic considered one of the oldest texts in human history (Mark, J. J., ; Mark, J. J., ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ).

Currently, the site where Uruk once thrived is part of the Ahwar archaeological site (UNESCO, Ahwar)

maps.text: Part of map of Asia highlighting the region from Mesopotamia to the Zagros Mountains in Iran, representing the areas occupied by the ancient Sumerians (Kessler, P. L., ). The area is marked approximately to provide the reader with a clearer visualization

history.text: The city of Uruk was divided into two main sections: the districts of *Eanna* and *Anu*. In this section, we analyze the descendants of Utu, who are the first to be mentioned in the Sumerian King List from the region of Uruk

history.text: The primary focus of this text is the *Sumerian King List*, and we follow its account by considering *Enmerkar* as the son of *Mec-ki-aj-gacer*. However, it is important to note that the epics *Enmerkar and the Lord of Aratta* and *Lugalbanda* describe *Enmerkar* as the son, not the grandson, of *Utu*

history.text: In the Mesopotamian region, evidence of human presence and cultural complexity can be observed as far back as the 6th millennium BCE. However, it was only during the 4th millennium BCE that these elements became more consolidated, particularly in the region of Uruk. The foundation of the city is estimated to have occurred around <htdate0>

source.text: Algaze, G. et al, pg. 574 - 577
Mark, J. J.

history.text: Figure 3: Fragment of the epic *Enmerkar and the lord of Aratta*. Â© Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford (Ashmolean Image Library).

*Enmerkar* is one of the most emblematic figures depicted in ancient Sumerian epics. Initially, it was believed that only one epic referenced him. However, recent research has shown that multiple epics feature this important figure. Among them, the *Epic Enmerkar and the lord of Aratta* stands out, recounting events deeply tied to the rich Sumerian culture. Below, we highlight some notable lines and themes from this epic

source.text: Black, J.A. et. all, Enmerkar and the lord of Aratta
Black, J.A. et. all (translation), Enmerkar and the lord of Aratta
Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia

history.text:
• Lines 242 - 273: Mountains are described as places for sacrifices and prayers.
  • Lines 308 - 338: Reference to the existence of a palace in heaven.
  • Lines 518 - 535: Mention of a tree that connects heaven and Earth.
  • Lines 308 - 338: Descriptions of the connections between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.
  • Lines 557 - 576: Accounts of a flood that destroyed everything and *Inana's* actions in its aftermath.
  • Paradise: The word "paradise" is mentioned 12 times throughout the epic.
  • Moutain: The term "mountain" appears 67 times, including two specific references to "seven mountains."
  • Inana: The goddess of wisdom, war, and love is mentioned 31 times.
According to the **Sumerian King List**, *Enmerkar*âs reign lasted **420 years**

source.text: Black, J.A. et. all, Sumerian King List, ln. 106
Black, J.A. et. all (translation), Sumerian King List, ln. 106

history.text:
Reflection 2: On Beliefs

The Babylonian version of the epic *Enmerkar and the Lord of Aratta* was written between and . This makes it older than any known sacred text still studied today. Furthermore, many of the concepts found in this epic also appear in later, more recent texts.

In light of this, what conclusions can you draw about the origins and transmission of ideas throughout history?
This is the second lineage associated with the city of Uruk, directly connected to Enmerkar through Sumerian epics that have survived to the present day

source.text: Mark, J. J.

history.text: *Lugalbanda* is mentioned as an ancestor of *Gilgamesh* according to the *Epic of Gilgamesh*. However, in the *Sumerian King List*, *Gilgamesh*'s father is only referenced as a phantom, leaving *Lugalbanda*'s direct connection as his progenitor ambiguous. This analysis follows the interpretation of J.J. Mark

source.text: The Epic of Gilgamesh, Tablet I
Black, J.A. et. all, Sumerian King List, ln. 95-133
Black, J.A. et. all (translation), ln. 95-133
Mark, J. J.

history.text: In the *Epic of Lugalbanda in the Mountain Cave*, it is described that *Lugalbanda* accompanies *Enmerkar* in a military campaign against the city of Aratta. During the journey, he falls ill on the eighth day. This epic incorporates symbolic references to Sumerian culture, such as bulls and floods

source.text: Black, J.A. et. all, Lugalbanda in the Mountain Cave
Black, J.A. et. all (translation), Lugalbanda in the Mountain Cave
Mark, J. J.

history.text: *Lugalbanda* is also the central figure of a second epic that bears his name and continues the story. After recovering from his illness, he reunites with *Enmerkar* and contributes to their victory over Aratta. This text highlights a significant characteristic of Mesopotamian culture: the interaction between humans and animals in Sumerian literature. Animals are often depicted with anthropomorphic traits, such as the ability to speak. The bird Anzud serves as a notable example of such features in this epic

source.text: Black, J.A. et. all, Lugalbanda
Black, J.A. et. all (translation), Lugalbanda
Mark, J. J.
Verderame, L.

history.text: However, when analyzing the events described in the epic and the existence of Gilgamesh, it is necessary to approach the subject with caution. While the epic does not provide verifiable descriptions of historical events, inscriptions on the walls of Uruk, attributed to this king, suggest that he may have indeed existed

history.text: The *Epic of Gilgamesh* is summarized in the encyclopedias used as references. Below, we highlight some of the main events recorded on each tablet

source.text: Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia
Mark, J. J.
The Epic of Gilgamesh

history.text:
Tablet Main Subject Comments
I Presentation of Gilgamesh as half-human and half-divine. He is described as a descendant of Lugalbanda and referred to as the "shepherd of Uruk-Haven." Lugalbanda is also mentioned in other epics analyzed. Frequent references to the number seven associate it with sages and days.
II Gilgamesh engages in tests of strength against another man and emerges victorious.  
III-V Gilgamesh and Enkidu confront Huwawa, the guardian of the cedar forest. These tablets are incompletes.
VI After returning to Uruk, Gilgamesh rejects a marriage proposal from Ishtar. With Enkidu's help, they kill the sacred bull. Bovines play a significant role in Sumerian beliefs, as also seen in the Epic of Lugalbanda.
VII Gilgamesh dreams that the gods have decided he must die for killing the sacred bull. Enkidu falls ill. In , Sigmund Freud later published a study on dream interpretation with a scientific lens, but in antiquity, dreams were viewed as a means of communication and prophecy (Freud, Sigmund).
VIII Enkidu dies, and his funeral is described.  
IX e X After Enkidu's death, Gilgamesh embarks on a journey to find Utnapishtim, the survivor of a great flood. Floods were frequent in Mesopotamia, between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. Research related to these floods is covered in the "Understanding Texts" section (Understanding Texts with Sciences
XI Utnapishtim recounts the flood and his survival. He mentions a plant that grants eternal youth, which Gilgamesh finds but is later stolen by a serpent.
Figure 5: The Flood Tablet. Tablet XI of Epic de Gilgamesh. Â© Trustees of the British Museum (The British Museum).

If some aspects of the *Epic of Gilgamesh* remind you of other ancient texts, this is no coincidence. As explained by J.J. Mark in the *World History Encyclopedia*, the epic incorporates ancient Mesopotamian beliefs that may have inspired other civilizations to craft their own narratives

source.text: Mark, J. J.

history.text: It is also important to note that the *Epic of Gilgamesh* as we know it today is a compilation of older texts. Some of these earlier texts also feature Gilgamesh in their titles, such as *Gilgamesh and Aga*, *Gilgamesh and the Bull of Heaven*, *The Death of Gilgamesh*, *Gilgamesh, Enkidu, and the Nether world*, and *Gilgamesh and Huwawa*

history.text:
Mathematics and Physics in History

When analyzing different Sumerian epics, we find mentions of the word "day." But did the "day" for the Sumerians mean the same as it does for us today? Or are we witnessing a semantic shiftâa process in which a word changes its meaning over time (Black, J.A. et. all, Gilgamesh and Aga, ; Black, J.A. et. all, Gilgamesh and Aga (traduction), ; Gilgamesh, Enkidu in the Nether World, ; Gilgamesh, Enkidu in the Nether World (traduction), ; Sabino, Marilei A., )?

H. Radau, in his study of ancient Sumerian cosmology, highlighted that the concept of day and night was tied to the movement of the Sun. He also introduced the idea of a "world-edifice," which refers to a cosmic structure. Years later, Samuel Noah Kramer delved deeper into this topic by analyzing various Sumerian tablets, including one preserved in the Pushkin Museum. Kramer revealed that the Sumerians believed the Sun continued its journey through the "Nether World" after sunset. This suggests that, for the Sumerians, the concept of "day" was not linked to the Earth's rotation, as it is understood today (Radau, H., ; Kramer, Samuel Noah, ).

When discussing the measurement of time, it is important to clarify a common misconception. While it is indisputable that the Sumerians used the sexagesimal numbering system, as noted by R. K. Englund, there is no evidence that this system was applied to divide the day into hours or minutes. Instead, it was primarily used for counting discrete objects, such as large quantities of goods (Englund, R. K., ).

According to Herodotus, the Greeks adopted the division of the day into 12-hour intervals from the Babylonians. The Babylonians divided time into two main periods: day and night, each consisting of 12 equal intervals. To achieve more precise measurements of time, devices such as sundials (sun clocks) and water clocks were developed later. However, the continuous measurement of time was only achieved during the Hellenistic period ( - ) (Cajori, Florian, , pp. 8 ; Dohrn-van Rossum, Gerhard, , pp. 17 - 28).

The modern definition of a day and the daily period considers the time it takes for the Earth to rotate around its axis relative to different frames of reference. When the reference is the position of the stars in space, this is known as the sidereal day, which lasts 86,164.0999 seconds. In contrast, when the reference is the Sun, we define the solar day, which has a duration of 86,400 seconds.

However, as highlighted by McCarthy, this duration is not constant over time. The Earth's rotation undergoes changes due to various factors, resulting in a variation of approximately 1.7 milliseconds per century (McCarthy DD, ).

In light of the advances in understanding the concept of 'day' from the Sumerians to the present, we conclude that interpreting the days mentioned in antiquity through the lens of our modern understanding would constitute an anachronism

source.text: Cambridge Dictionary

history.text:
Reflection 3: On the passage of time (Part I)

In a video about the Sumerian King List, Cy points out that some ancient Sumerian writers faced the same challenge we do: a lack of reliable information. As a result, they likely relied on oral traditions to document their kings, such as Enmenbaresi. Consequently, this led to descriptions of reigns with impossibly long durations (Hystory with Cy).

Can you think of another explanation for why some reigns were described as lasting so long?
According to *Sumerian King List*

Black, J.A. et. all (translation), Lista dos Reis SumÃ©rios, ln. 95-133

history.text: It is important to emphasize to readers that Dumuzid, the Fisherman, should not be confused with the homonymous figure mentioned in the pre-flood period, as indicated by his epithet

source.text: Black, J.A. et. all, Sumerian King List, ln. 109-111
Black, J.A. et. all (translation), Sumerian King List, ln. 109-111

history.text:
Reflection 4: On the passage of time (Part I)

The analysis of texts must consider not only the historical context in which they were written but also the development of the writing systems of each epoch.

For example, the Phoenician alphabet may have been influenced by the Egyptians and was created around the 11th century BCE. As a result, it is more recent than any cuneiform texts written by the Babylonians and Sumerians, which already mentioned concepts such as the deluge and paradise. This alphabet is recognized as the first documented alphabetic writing system (Ashmolean Image Library, Lista dos Reis SumÃ©rios ; Ashmolean Image Library, Enmerkar e o Senhor de Aratta ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia ; Thamis).

Considering that the Sumerians and Babylonians were the first to record beliefs that persist to this day, is it possible that they were also the first to spread these ideas?

The reign of Dumuzid, the Fisherman, has been interpreted in various ways over time based on the available information. Initially, there was uncertainty about his natureâwhether he was a divine or human figure. Another issue arose from early translations of the *Sumerian King List*. In the initial interpretation, it was believed that Dumuzid captured Enmebaragesi. However, more recent translations suggest the opposite: Enmebaragesi captured Dumuzid. This revised interpretation is further supported by the fact that Dumuzid has no successors mentioned in the list

source.text: black, j.a. et. all, lista dos reis sumÃ©rios, ln. 109-111

exercise_v2.question: Did the Sumerians understand the heaven as a level similar to Earth, one that could be reached?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The epic Enmerkar and the Lord Aratta mentions a tree that connects the Earth to Heaven. Additionally, it describes a palace in paradise, which, by definition, is built on something. These elements suggest that the Sumerians had a vision of the sky different from the one we have today.

exercise_v2.question: Was the Sumerian concept of 'day' the same as our current understanding?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Although the Sumerians developed the sexagesimal system and their texts mention the word 'day,' there is no evidence in ancient texts that confirms an understanding of time similar to ours. Therefore, it is incorrect to assert that the concept of 'day' used by the Sumerians was the same as ours.
